The **giraffe** (_Giraffa_) is a [genus](/wiki/Genus "Genus") of African
[even-toed ungulate](/wiki/Even-toed_ungulate "Even-toed ungulate")
[mammals](/wiki/Mammal "Mammal"), the [tallest](/wiki/Largest_mammals#Even-
toed_Ungulates_\(Artiodactyla\) "Largest mammals") living terrestrial animals
and the largest [ruminants](/wiki/Ruminant "Ruminant"). The genus currently
consists of one species, _Giraffa camelopardalis_ , the [type
species](/wiki/Type_species "Type species"). Seven other species are extinct,
prehistoric species known from fossils. Taxonomic classifications of one to
eight extant giraffe species have been described, based upon research into the
[mitochondrial](/wiki/Mitochondrial_DNA "Mitochondrial DNA") and [nuclear
DNA](/wiki/Nuclear_DNA "Nuclear DNA"), as well as morphological measurements
of _Giraffa,_ but the IUCN currently recognises only one species with nine
subspecies.

The giraffe's chief distinguishing characteristics are its extremely long neck
and legs, its horn-like [ossicones](/wiki/Ossicone "Ossicone"), and its
distinctive coat patterns. It is classified under the
[family](/wiki/Family_\(biology\) "Family \(biology\)")
[Giraffidae](/wiki/Giraffidae "Giraffidae"), along with its closest extant
relative, the [okapi](/wiki/Okapi "Okapi"). Its scattered range extends from
[Chad](/wiki/Chad "Chad") in the north to [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa
"South Africa") in the south, and from [Niger](/wiki/Niger "Niger") in the
west to [Somalia](/wiki/Somalia "Somalia") in the east. Giraffes usually
inhabit [savannahs](/wiki/Savannah "Savannah") and [woodlands](/wiki/Woodland
"Woodland"). Their food source is leaves, fruits and flowers of woody plants,
primarily [acacia](/wiki/Acacieae "Acacieae") species, which they browse at
heights most other herbivores cannot reach. They may be preyed on by
[lions](/wiki/Lion "Lion"), [leopards](/wiki/Leopard "Leopard"), [spotted
hyenas](/wiki/Spotted_hyena "Spotted hyena") and [African wild
dogs](/wiki/African_wild_dog "African wild dog"). Giraffes live in herds of
related females and their offspring, or bachelor herds of unrelated adult
males, but are gregarious and may gather in large aggregations. Males
establish social hierarchies through "necking", which are combat bouts where
the neck is used as a weapon. [Dominant](/wiki/Dominance_\(ethology\)
"Dominance \(ethology\)") males gain mating access to females, which bear the
sole responsibility for raising the young.

The giraffe has intrigued various cultures, both ancient and modern, for its
peculiar appearance, and has often been featured in paintings, books, and
cartoons. It is classified by the [International Union for Conservation of
Nature](/wiki/International_Union_for_Conservation_of_Nature "International
Union for Conservation of Nature") as [Vulnerable](/wiki/Vulnerable_species
"Vulnerable species") to extinction, and has been
[extirpated](/wiki/Local_extinction "Local extinction") from many parts of its
former range. Giraffes are still found in numerous [national
parks](/wiki/National_park "National park") and [game
reserves](/wiki/Game_reserve "Game reserve") but estimations as of 2016
indicate that there are approximately 97,500 members of _Giraffa_ in the wild,
with around 1,144 in captivity.

## Etymology

The name "giraffe" has its earliest known origins in the
[Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language "Arabic language") word _zarāfah_ (زرافة),[2]
perhaps borrowed from the animal's [Somali](/wiki/Somali_language "Somali
language") name _geri_.[3] The Arab name is translated as "fast-walker".[4]
There were several [Middle English](/wiki/Middle_English "Middle English")
spellings, such as _jarraf_ , _ziraph_ , and _gerfauntz_.[2] The
[Italian](/wiki/Italian_language "Italian language") form _giraffa_ arose in
the 1590s.[2] The modern English form developed around 1600 from the
[French](/wiki/French_language "French language") _girafe_.[2] "Camelopard" is
an archaic English name for the giraffe deriving from the [Ancient
Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek") for camel and leopard, referring
to its [camel](/wiki/Camel "Camel")-like shape and its [leopard](/wiki/Leopard
"Leopard")-like colouring.[5][6]

## Taxonomy

Living giraffes were originally classified as one species by [Carl
Linnaeus](/wiki/Carl_Linnaeus "Carl Linnaeus") in 1758. He gave it the
binomial name _[Cervus](/wiki/Cervus "Cervus") camelopardalis_. [Morten Thrane
Brünnich](/wiki/Morten_Thrane_Br%C3%BCnnich "Morten Thrane Brünnich")
classified the genus _Giraffa_ in 1772.[7] The species name _camelopardalis_
is from [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin").[8]

The giraffe is one of only two living genera of the family
[Giraffidae](/wiki/Giraffidae "Giraffidae") in the order
[Artiodactyla](/wiki/Artiodactyla "Artiodactyla"), the other being the
[okapi](/wiki/Okapi "Okapi"). The family was once much more extensive, with
over 10 fossil [genera](/wiki/Genus "Genus") described. Their closest known
relatives are the extinct deer-like [climacocerids](/wiki/Climacoceratidae
"Climacoceratidae"). They, together with the family
[Antilocapridae](/wiki/Antilocapridae "Antilocapridae") (whose only extant
species is the [pronghorn](/wiki/Pronghorn "Pronghorn")), belong to the
superfamily [Giraffoidea](/wiki/Giraffoidea "Giraffoidea"). These animals may
have evolved from the extinct family [Palaeomerycidae](/wiki/Palaeomerycidae
"Palaeomerycidae") which might also have been the ancestor of
[deer](/wiki/Deer "Deer").[11]

The elongation of the neck appears to have started early in the giraffe
[lineage](/wiki/Lineage_\(evolution\) "Lineage \(evolution\)"). Comparisons
between giraffes and their ancient relatives suggest that vertebrae close to
the skull lengthened earlier, followed by lengthening of vertebrae further
down.[12] One early giraffid ancestor was _[Canthumeryx](/wiki/Canthumeryx
"Canthumeryx")_ which has been dated variously to have lived 25–20 million
years ago (mya), 17–15 mya or 18–14.3 mya and whose deposits have been found
in Libya. This animal was medium-sized, slender and antelope-like.
_[Giraffokeryx](/wiki/Giraffokeryx "Giraffokeryx")_ appeared 15 mya in the
[Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent") and
resembled an okapi or a small giraffe, and had a longer neck and similar
[ossicones](/wiki/Ossicones "Ossicones").[11] _Giraffokeryx_ may have shared a
clade with more massively built giraffids like
_[Sivatherium](/wiki/Sivatherium "Sivatherium")_ and
_[Bramatherium](/wiki/Bramatherium "Bramatherium")_.[12]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Giraffidcomparison.jpg/170px-
Giraffidcomparison.jpg)](/wiki/File:Giraffidcomparison.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Giraffidcomparison.jpg "Enlarge")

The extinct giraffid _[Samotherium](/wiki/Samotherium "Samotherium")_ (middle)
in comparison with the okapi (below) and giraffe. The anatomy of _Samotherium_
appears to have shown a transition to a giraffe-like neck.[13]

Giraffids like _[Palaeotragus](/wiki/Palaeotragus "Palaeotragus")_ ,
_[Shansitherium](/wiki/Shansitherium "Shansitherium")_ and
_[Samotherium](/wiki/Samotherium "Samotherium")_ appeared 14 mya and lived
throughout Africa and Eurasia. These animals had bare ossicones and small
cranial sinuses and were longer with broader skulls.[11][12] _Paleotragus_
resembled the okapi and may have been its ancestor.[11] Others find that the
okapi lineage diverged earlier, before _Giraffokeryx_.[12] _Samotherium_ was a
particularly important [transitional fossil](/wiki/Transitional_fossil
"Transitional fossil") in the giraffe lineage as its cervical vertebrae was
intermediate in length and structure between a modern giraffe and an okapi,
and was more vertical than the okapi's.[13] _[Bohlinia](/wiki/Bohlinia
"Bohlinia")_ , which first appeared in southeastern Europe and lived 9–7 mya
was likely a direct ancestor of the giraffe. _Bohlinia_ closely resembled
modern giraffes, having a long neck and legs and similar ossicones and
dentition.[11]

_Bohlinia_ entered China and northern India in response to climate change.
From there, the genus _[Giraffa](/wiki/Giraffa "Giraffa")_ evolved and, around
7 mya, entered Africa.[14] Further climate changes caused the extinction of
the Asian giraffes, while the African giraffes survived and radiated into
several new species. Living giraffes appear to have arisen around 1 mya in
eastern Africa during the [Pleistocene](/wiki/Pleistocene "Pleistocene").[11]
Some biologists suggest the modern giraffes descended from _[G.
jumae](/wiki/Giraffa_jumae "Giraffa jumae")_ ;[15] others find _[G.
gracilis](/w/index.php?title=Giraffa_gracilis&action=edit&redlink=1 "Giraffa
gracilis \(page does not exist\)")_ a more likely candidate.[11] _G. jumae_
was larger and more heavily built while _G. gracilis_ was smaller and more
lightly built. The main driver for the evolution of the giraffes is believed
to have been the changes from extensive forests to more open habitats, which
began 8 mya.[11] During this time, tropical plants disappeared and were
replaced by arid [C4 plants](/wiki/C4_plant "C4 plant"), and a dry savannah
emerged across eastern and northern Africa and western India.[16][17] Some
researchers have hypothesised that this new habitat coupled with a different
diet, including acacia species, may have exposed giraffe ancestors to toxins
that caused higher mutation rates and a higher rate of evolution.[18] The coat
patterns of modern giraffes may also have coincided with these habitat
changes. Asian giraffes are hypothesised to have had more okapi-like
colourations.[11]

In the early 19th century, [Jean-Baptiste Lamarck](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Lamarck
"Jean-Baptiste Lamarck") believed the giraffe's long neck was an "acquired
characteristic", developed as generations of ancestral giraffes strove to
reach the leaves of tall trees.[19] This theory was eventually rejected, and
scientists now believe the giraffe's neck arose through Darwinian [natural
selection](/wiki/Natural_selection "Natural selection")—that ancestral
giraffes with long necks thereby had a competitive feeding advantage
(competing browsers hypothesis)[20] that better enabled them to survive and
reproduce to pass on their genes.[19]

The giraffe [genome](/wiki/Genome "Genome") is around 2.9 billion [base
pairs](/wiki/Base_pair "Base pair") in length compared to the 3.3 billion base
pairs of the okapi. Of the proteins in giraffe and okapi genes, 19.4% are
identical. The two species are equally distantly related to cattle, suggesting
the giraffe's unique characteristics are not because of faster evolution. The
[divergence](/wiki/Divergent_evolution "Divergent evolution") of giraffe and
okapi lineages dates to around 11.5 mya. A small group of [regulatory
genes](/wiki/Regulatory_gene "Regulatory gene") in the giraffe appear to be
responsible for the animal's stature and associated circulatory
adaptations.[21]

### Species and subspecies

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Genetic_subdivision_in_the_giraffe_based_on_mitochondrial_DNA_sequences.png/220px-
Genetic_subdivision_in_the_giraffe_based_on_mitochondrial_DNA_sequences.png)](/wiki/File:Genetic_subdivision_in_the_giraffe_based_on_mitochondrial_DNA_sequences.png)

[](/wiki/File:Genetic_subdivision_in_the_giraffe_based_on_mitochondrial_DNA_sequences.png
"Enlarge")

"Approximate geographic ranges, fur patterns, and
[phylogenetic](/wiki/Phylogenetics "Phylogenetics") relationships between some
giraffe subspecies based on [mitochondrial DNA](/wiki/Mitochondrial_DNA
"Mitochondrial DNA") sequences. Colored dots on the map represent sampling
localities. The phylogenetic tree is a [maximum-likelihood](/wiki/Maximum-
likelihood "Maximum-likelihood")
[phylogram](/wiki/Phylogenetic_tree#Special_tree_types "Phylogenetic tree")
based on samples from 266 giraffes. Asterisks along branches correspond to
[node](/wiki/Clade#Definitions "Clade") values of more than 90%
[bootstrap](/wiki/Resampling_\(statistics\) "Resampling \(statistics\)")
support. Stars at branch tips identify [paraphyletic](/wiki/Paraphyletic
"Paraphyletic") [haplotypes](/wiki/Haplotype "Haplotype") found in Maasai and
reticulated giraffes".[22]

The IUCN currently recognises only one species of giraffe with nine
subspecies.[23][24] In 2001, a two-species taxonomy was proposed.[25] A 2007
study on the genetics of _Giraffa_ , suggested they were six species: the West
African, Rothschild's, reticulated, Masai, Angolan, and South African
giraffe.[22] The study deduced from genetic differences in
[nuclear](/wiki/Nuclear_DNA "Nuclear DNA") and [mitochondrial
DNA](/wiki/Mitochondrial_DNA "Mitochondrial DNA") (mtDNA) that giraffes from
these populations are [reproductively isolated](/wiki/Reproductive_isolation
"Reproductive isolation") and rarely interbreed, though no natural obstacles
block their mutual access. This includes adjacent populations of Rothschild's,
reticulated, and Masai giraffes. The Masai giraffe was also suggested to
consist of possibly two species separated by the [Rift
Valley](/wiki/East_African_Rift "East African Rift").[22]

Reticulated and Masai giraffes have the highest mtDNA diversity, which is
consistent with giraffes originating in eastern Africa. Populations further
north are more closely related to the former, while those to the south are
more related to the latter. Giraffes appear to select mates of the same coat
type, which are imprinted on them as calves.[22] The implications of these
findings for the conservation of giraffes were summarised by David Brown, lead
author of the study, who told [BBC News](/wiki/BBC_News "BBC News"): "Lumping
all giraffes into one species obscures the reality that some kinds of giraffe
are on the brink. Some of these populations number only a few hundred
individuals and need immediate protection."[26]

A 2011 study using detailed analyses of the morphology of giraffes, and
application of the [phylogenetic species concept](/wiki/Species "Species"),
described eight species of living giraffes.[27] The eight species are: _[G.
angolensis](/wiki/Angolan_giraffe "Angolan giraffe")_ ,
_[G.antiquorum](/wiki/Kordofan_giraffe "Kordofan giraffe")_ , _[G.
camelopardalis](/wiki/Nubian_giraffe "Nubian giraffe")_ , _[G.
giraffa](/wiki/South_African_giraffe "South African giraffe")_ , _[G.
peralta](/wiki/West_African_giraffe "West African giraffe")_ , _[G.
reticulata](/wiki/Reticulated_giraffe "Reticulated giraffe")_ , _[G.
thornicrofti](/wiki/Rhodesian_giraffe "Rhodesian giraffe")_ , and _[G.
tippelskirchi](/wiki/Masai_giraffe "Masai giraffe")_.

A 2016 study also concluded that living giraffes consist of multiple
species.[28] The researchers suggested the existence of four species, which
have not exchanged genetic information between each other for 1 million to 2
million years. Those four species are the [northern
giraffe](/wiki/Northern_giraffe "Northern giraffe") (_G. camelopardalis_),
[southern giraffe](/wiki/Southern_giraffe "Southern giraffe") (_G. giraffa_),
[reticulated giraffe](/wiki/Reticulated_giraffe "Reticulated giraffe") (_G.
reticulata_), and [Masai giraffe](/wiki/Masai_giraffe "Masai giraffe") (_G.
tippelskirchi_).[28] Since then, a response to this publication has been
published, highlighting seven problems in data interpretation, and concludes
"the conclusions should not be accepted unconditionally".[29]

There are an estimated 90,000 individuals of _Giraffa_ in the wild, with 1,144
currently in captivity.[28][30]

There are also seven extinct species of giraffe, listed as the following:

  * [†](/wiki/Extinction "Extinction") _[Giraffa gracilis](/w/index.php?title=Giraffa_gracilis&action=edit&redlink=1 "Giraffa gracilis \(page does not exist\)")_
  * † _[Giraffa jumae](/wiki/Giraffa_jumae "Giraffa jumae")_
  * † _[Giraffa priscilla](/wiki/Giraffa_priscilla "Giraffa priscilla")_
  * † _[Giraffa punjabiensis](/w/index.php?title=Giraffa_punjabiensis&action=edit&redlink=1 "Giraffa punjabiensis \(page does not exist\)")_
  * † _[Giraffa pygmaea](/wiki/Giraffa_pygmaea "Giraffa pygmaea")_
  * † _[Giraffa sivalensis](/wiki/Giraffa_sivalensis "Giraffa sivalensis")_
  * † _[Giraffa stillei](/wiki/Giraffa_stillei "Giraffa stillei")_

_G. attica_ , also extinct, was formerly considered part of _Giraffa_ but was
reclassified as _[Bohlinia attica](/wiki/Bohlinia "Bohlinia")_ in 1929.

---|---|---|---|---  
**Giraffe** (G. camelopardalis)[24][23] | **[Northern giraffe](/wiki/Northern_giraffe "Northern giraffe")** (_G. camelopardalis_) | **[Kordofan giraffe](/wiki/Kordofan_giraffe "Kordofan giraffe")** (_G. antiquorum_)[31] | The **[Kordofan giraffe](/wiki/Kordofan_giraffe "Kordofan giraffe")** (_G. c. antiquorum_) has a distribution which includes southern [Chad](/wiki/Chad "Chad"), the [Central African Republic](/wiki/Central_African_Republic "Central African Republic"), northern [Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroon "Cameroon"), and north-eastern [DR Congo](/wiki/Democratic_Republic_of_the_Congo "Democratic Republic of the Congo").[24] Populations in Cameroon were formerly included in _G. c. peralta_ , but this was incorrect.[32] Compared to the Nubian giraffe, this subspecies has smaller and more irregular spotting patterns. Its spots may be found below the hocks and the insides of the legs. A median lump is present in males.[33]:51–52 Some 2,000 are believed to remain in the wild.[24] Considerable confusion has existed over the status of this species and _G. c. peralta_ in zoos. In 2007, all alleged _G. c. peralta_ in [European zoos](/wiki/List_of_zoos#Europe "List of zoos") were shown to be, in fact, _G. c. antiquorum_.[32] With this correction, about 65 are kept in zoos.[30] The formerly recognised subspecies _G. c. congoesis_ is now considered part of Kordofan species. | [![Giraffa camelopardalis antiquorum \(Vincennes Zoo\) 2.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Giraffa_camelopardalis_antiquorum_%28Vincennes_Zoo%29_2.jpg/150px-Giraffa_camelopardalis_antiquorum_%28Vincennes_Zoo%29_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Giraffa_camelopardalis_antiquorum_\(Vincennes_Zoo\)_2.jpg)  
**[Nubian giraffe](/wiki/Nubian_giraffe "Nubian giraffe")** including **[Rothschild's giraffe](/wiki/Rothschild%27s_giraffe "Rothschild's giraffe")** (_G. camelopardalis_)[23] also known as **[Baringo](/wiki/Lake_Baringo "Lake Baringo") giraffe** or **[Ugandan](/wiki/Uganda "Uganda") giraffe** | The **[Nubian giraffe](/wiki/Nubian_giraffe "Nubian giraffe")** (_G. c. camelopardalis_), is found in eastern [South Sudan](/wiki/South_Sudan "South Sudan") and south-western [Ethiopia](/wiki/Ethiopia "Ethiopia"), in addition to [Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya") and [Uganda](/wiki/Uganda "Uganda").[24] It has sharply defined chestnut-coloured spots surrounded by mostly white lines, while undersides lack spotting.[34] The median lump is particularly developed in the male.[33]:51 Around 2,150 are thought to remain in the wild, with another 1,500 individuals belonging to the [Rothschild](/wiki/Rothschild%27s_giraffe "Rothschild's giraffe") [ecotype](/wiki/Ecotype "Ecotype").[24] With the addition of [Rothschild's giraffe](/wiki/Rothschild%27s_giraffe "Rothschild's giraffe") to the Nubian subspecies, the Nubian giraffe is very common in captivity, although the original phenotype is rare- a group is kept at [Al Ain Zoo](/wiki/Al_Ain_Zoo "Al Ain Zoo") in the [United Arab Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates "United Arab Emirates").[35] In 2003, this group numbered 14.[36] The **[Rothschild's giraffe](/wiki/Rothschild%27s_giraffe "Rothschild's giraffe")** (_G. c. rothschildi_) may be an [ecotype](/wiki/Ecotype "Ecotype") of _G. camelopardalis_. Its range includes parts of Uganda and Kenya.[24] Its presence in South Sudan is uncertain.[37] This giraffe has large dark patches that usually have complete margins, but may also have sharp edges. The dark spots may also have paler radiating lines or streaks within them. Spotting does not often reach below the hocks and almost never to the hooves. This ecotype may also develop five "horns".[33]:53 Around 1,500 individuals believed to remain in the wild,[24] and more than 450 are kept in zoos.[30] According to genetic analysis circa September 2016, it is [conspecific](/wiki/Biological_specificity "Biological specificity") with the [Nubian giraffe](/wiki/Nubian_giraffe "Nubian giraffe") (_G. c. camelopardalis_).[28] | [![Al Ain Zoo Giraffe.JPG](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Al_Ain_Zoo_Giraffe.JPG/150px-Al_Ain_Zoo_Giraffe.JPG)](/wiki/File:Al_Ain_Zoo_Giraffe.JPG)

The ossicones are more erect than in other subspecies and males have well-developed median lumps.[33]:52–53 It is the most endangered subspecies within _Giraffa_ , with 400 individuals remaining in the wild.[24] Giraffes in Cameroon were formerly believed to belong to this species, but are actually _G. c. antiquorum_.[32] This error resulted in some confusion over its status in zoos, but in 2007, it was established that all "_G. c. peralta_ " kept in European zoos actually are _G. c. antiquorum_. Fully grown giraffes stand 4.3–5.7 m (14.1–18.7 ft) tall, with males taller
than females.[47][48][49] The tallest recorded male was 5.88 m (19.3 ft) and
the tallest recorded female was 5.17 m (17.0 ft) tall.[47][50] The average
weight is 1,192 kg (2,628 lb) for an adult male and 828 kg (1,825 lb) for an
adult female[51] with maximum weights of 1,930 kg (4,250 lb) and 1,180 kg
(2,600 lb) having been recorded for males and females, respectively.[48][49]
Despite its long neck and legs, the giraffe's body is relatively short.[52]:66
Located at both sides of the head, the giraffe's large, bulging eyes give it
good all-round vision from its great height.[53]:25 Giraffes see in
colour[53]:26 and their senses of hearing and [smell](/wiki/Olfaction
"Olfaction") are also sharp.[19] The animal can close its muscular nostrils to
protect against sandstorms and ants.[53]:27

The giraffe's [prehensile](/wiki/Prehensile "Prehensile") tongue is about 45
cm (18 in) long.[48][49] It is purplish-black in colour, perhaps to protect
against sunburn, and is useful for grasping foliage, as well as for grooming
and cleaning the animal's nose.[53]:27 The upper lip of the giraffe is also
prehensile and useful when foraging and is covered in hair to protect against
thorns. The tongue, and inside of the mouth are covered in
[papillae](/wiki/Taste_bud "Taste bud").[7]

atTobuZoo-2012.ogv/220px--Giraffa_camelopardalis_reticulata-
atTobuZoo-2012.ogv.jpg)[Play

[](/wiki/File:Giraffa_camelopardalis_reticulata-atTobuZoo-2012.ogv "Enlarge")

(video) A pair of giraffes at [Tobu Zoo](/wiki/Tobu_Zoo "Tobu Zoo"), in
[Saitama](/wiki/Saitama_prefecture "Saitama prefecture"), Japan

The coat has dark blotches or patches (which can be orange,
[chestnut](/wiki/Chestnut_\(color\) "Chestnut \(color\)"), brown, or nearly
black in colour[19]) separated by light hair (usually white or
[cream](/wiki/Cream_\(colour\) "Cream \(colour\)") in colour[19]). Male
giraffes become darker as they age.[45] The coat pattern has been claimed to
serve as [camouflage](/wiki/Camouflage "Camouflage") in the light and shade
patterns of savannah woodlands.[46] While adult giraffes standing among trees
and bushes are hard to see at even a few metres' distance, they actively move
into the open to gain the best view of an approaching predator, obviating any
benefit that camouflage might bring. Instead, the adults rely on their size
and ability to defend themselves. However, camouflage appears to be important
for calves, which spend a large part of the day in hiding, away from their
mothers; further, over half of all calves die within a year, so predation is
certainly important. It appears, therefore, that the spotted coat of the
giraffe functions as camouflage for the young, while adults simply inherit
this coloration as a by-product.[11] The skin underneath the dark areas may
serve as windows for [thermoregulation](/wiki/Thermoregulation
"Thermoregulation"), being sites for complex blood vessel systems and large
sweat glands.[54] Each individual giraffe has a unique coat pattern.[45]

The skin of a giraffe is mostly gray.[51] Its thickness allows the animal to
run through thorn bush without being punctured.[53]:34 The fur may serve as a
chemical defence, as its parasite repellents give the animal a characteristic
scent. At least 11 main [aromatic](/wiki/Aromaticity "Aromaticity") chemicals
are in the fur, although [indole](/wiki/Indole "Indole") and
[3-methylindole](/wiki/3-methylindole "3-methylindole") are responsible for
most of the smell. Because the males have a stronger odour than the females,
the odour may also have sexual function.[55] Along the animal's neck is a mane
made of short, erect hairs.[7] The one-metre (3.3-ft) tail ends in a long,
dark tuft of hair and is used as a defense against insects.[53]:36

### Skull and ossicones

Both sexes have prominent horn-like structures called ossicones, which are
formed from ossified cartilage, covered in skin and fused to the skull at the
[parietal bones](/wiki/Parietal_bone "Parietal bone").[45] Being
[vascularized](/wiki/Vascular "Vascular"), the ossicones may have a role in
thermoregulation,[54] and are also used in combat between males.[56]
Appearance is a reliable guide to the sex or age of a giraffe: the ossicones
of females and young are thin and display tufts of hair on top, whereas those
of adult males end in knobs and tend to be bald on top.[45] Also, a median
lump, which is more prominent in males, emerges at the front of the
[skull](/wiki/Skull "Skull").[7] Males develop [calcium](/wiki/Calcium
"Calcium") deposits that form bumps on their skulls as they age.[19] A
giraffe's skull is lightened by multiple [sinuses](/wiki/Sinus_\(anatomy\)
"Sinus \(anatomy\)").[52]:70 However, as males age, their skulls become
heavier and more club-like, helping them become more dominant in combat.[45]
The upper jaw has a grooved [palate](/wiki/Palate "Palate") and lacks front
teeth.[53]:26 The giraffe's [molars](/wiki/Molar_\(tooth\) "Molar \(tooth\)")
have a rough surface.[53]:27

### Legs, locomotion and posture

The front and back legs of a giraffe are about the same length. The
[radius](/wiki/Radius_\(bone\) "Radius \(bone\)") and [ulna](/wiki/Ulna
"Ulna") of the front legs are articulated by the [carpus](/wiki/Carpus
"Carpus"), which, while structurally equivalent to the human wrist, functions
as a knee.[57] It appears that a [suspensory
ligament](/wiki/Suspensory_ligament "Suspensory ligament") allows the lanky
legs to support the animal's great weight.[58] The foot of the giraffe reaches
a diameter of 30 cm (12 in), and the [hoof](/wiki/Hoof "Hoof") is 15 cm (5.9
in) high in males and 10 cm (3.9 in) in females.[53]:36 The rear of each hoof
is low and the [fetlock](/wiki/Fetlock "Fetlock") is close to the ground,
allowing the foot to provide additional support to the animal's weight.[7]
Giraffes lack [dewclaws](/wiki/Dewclaw "Dewclaw") and interdigital glands. The
giraffe's pelvis, though relatively short, has an [ilium](/wiki/Ilium_\(bone\)
"Ilium \(bone\)") that is outspread at the upper ends.[7]

A giraffe has only two [gaits](/wiki/Gait "Gait"): walking and galloping.
Walking is done by moving the legs on one side of the body at the same time,
then doing the same on the other side.[45] When galloping, the hind legs move
around the front legs before the latter move forward,[19] and the tail will
curl up.[45] The animal relies on the forward and backward motions of its head
and neck to maintain balance and the counter momentum while
galloping.[40]:327–29 The giraffe can reach a sprint speed of up to 60 km/h
(37 mph),[59] and can sustain 50 km/h (31 mph) for several kilometres.[60]

A giraffe rests by lying with its body on top of its folded legs.[40]:329 To
lie down, the animal kneels on its front legs and then lowers the rest of its
body. To get back up, it first gets on its knees and spreads its hind legs to
raise its hindquarters. It then straightens its front legs. With each step,
the animal swings its head.[53]:31 In captivity, the giraffe sleeps
intermittently around 4.6 hours per day, mostly at night.[61] It usually
sleeps lying down, however, standing sleeps have been recorded, particularly
in older individuals. Intermittent short "deep sleep" phases while lying are
characterised by the giraffe bending its neck backwards and resting its head
on the hip or thigh, a position believed to indicate [paradoxical
sleep](/wiki/Paradoxical_sleep "Paradoxical sleep").[61] If the giraffe wants
to bend down to drink, it either spreads its front legs or bends its
knees.[45] Giraffes would probably not be competent swimmers as their long
legs would be highly cumbersome in the water,[62] although they could possibly
float.[63] When swimming, the thorax would be weighed down by the front legs,
making it difficult for the animal to move its neck and legs in
harmony[62][63] or keep its head above the surface.[62]

### Neck

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Okapi_Giraffe_Neck.png/220px-
Okapi_Giraffe_Neck.png)](/wiki/File:Okapi_Giraffe_Neck.png)

[](/wiki/File:Okapi_Giraffe_Neck.png "Enlarge")

The giraffe (right) and its close relative the okapi (left) both have seven
cervical vertebrae

The giraffe has an extremely elongated neck, which can be up to 2–2.4 m
(6.6–7.9 ft) in length, accounting for much of the animal's vertical
height.[48][49][53]:29[64] The long neck results from a disproportionate
lengthening of the [cervical vertebrae](/wiki/Cervical_vertebrae "Cervical
vertebrae"), not from the addition of more vertebrae. Each cervical vertebra
is over 28 cm (11 in) long.[52]:71 They comprise 52–54 per cent of the length
of the giraffe's [vertebral column](/wiki/Vertebral_column "Vertebral
column"), compared with the 27–33 percent typical of similar large ungulates,
including the giraffe’s closest living relative, the [okapi](/wiki/Okapi
"Okapi").[18] This elongation largely takes place after birth, perhaps because
giraffe mothers would have a difficult time giving birth to young with the
same neck proportions as adults.[65] The giraffe's head and neck are held up
by large muscles and a strengthened [nuchal ligament](/wiki/Nuchal_ligament
"Nuchal ligament"), which are anchored by long dorsal spines on the anterior
[thoracic vertebrae](/wiki/Thoracic_vertebrae "Thoracic vertebrae"), giving
the animal a hump.[7][66]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Flickr_-_Rainbirder_-
_High-rise_living.jpg/170px-Flickr_-_Rainbirder_-_High-
rise_living.jpg)](/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Rainbirder_-_High-rise_living.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Rainbirder_-_High-rise_living.jpg "Enlarge")

Adult male [reticulated giraffe](/wiki/Reticulated_giraffe "Reticulated
giraffe") feeding high up on an acacia, in [Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya")

The giraffe's neck vertebrae have [ball and socket
joints](/wiki/Ball_and_socket_joint "Ball and socket joint").[52]:71 In
particular, the [atlas](/wiki/Atlas_\(anatomy\) "Atlas
\(anatomy\)")–[axis](/wiki/Axis_\(anatomy\) "Axis \(anatomy\)") joint (C1 and
C2) allows the animal to tilt its head vertically and reach more branches with
the tongue.[53]:29 The point of articulation between the cervical and thoracic
vertebrae of giraffes is shifted to lie between the first and second thoracic
vertebrae (T1 and T2), unlike most other ruminants where the articulation is
between the seventh cervical vertebra (C7) and T1.[18][65] This allows C7 to
contribute directly to increased neck length and has given rise to the
suggestion that T1 is actually C8, and that giraffes have added an extra
cervical vertebra.[66] However, this proposition is not generally accepted, as
T1 has other morphological features, such as an articulating [rib](/wiki/Rib
"Rib"), deemed diagnostic of thoracic vertebrae, and because exceptions to the
mammalian limit of seven cervical vertebrae are generally characterised by
increased [neurological anomalies](/wiki/Neurological_disorder "Neurological
disorder") and maladies.[18]

There are several hypotheses regarding the evolutionary origin and maintenance
of elongation in giraffe necks.[56] The "competing
[browsers](/wiki/Browsing_\(predation\) "Browsing \(predation\)") hypothesis"
was originally suggested by [Charles Darwin](/wiki/Charles_Darwin "Charles
Darwin") and challenged only recently. It suggests that competitive pressure
from smaller browsers, such as [kudu](/wiki/Kudu "Kudu"),
[steenbok](/wiki/Steenbok "Steenbok") and [impala](/wiki/Impala "Impala"),
encouraged the elongation of the neck, as it enabled giraffes to reach food
that competitors could not. This advantage is real, as giraffes can and do
feed up to 4.5 m (15 ft) high, while even quite large competitors, such as
kudu, can feed up to only about 2 m (6 ft 7 in) high.[67] There is also
research suggesting that browsing competition is intense at lower levels, and
giraffes feed more efficiently (gaining more leaf biomass with each mouthful)
high in the canopy.[68][69] However, scientists disagree about just how much
time giraffes spend feeding at levels beyond the reach of other
browsers,[15][56][67][70] and a 2010 study found that adult giraffes with
longer necks actually suffered higher mortality rates under drought conditions
than their shorter-necked counterparts. This study suggests that maintaining a
longer neck requires more nutrients, which puts longer-necked giraffes at risk
during a food shortage.[71]

Another theory, the [sexual selection](/wiki/Sexual_selection "Sexual
selection") hypothesis, proposes that the long necks evolved as a secondary
[sexual characteristic](/wiki/Sexual_dimorphism "Sexual dimorphism"), giving
males an advantage in "necking" contests (see below) to establish dominance
and obtain access to sexually receptive females.[15] In support of this
theory, necks are longer and heavier for males than females of the same
age,[15][56] and the former do not employ other forms of combat.[15] However,
one objection is that it fails to explain why female giraffes also have long
necks.[72] It has also been proposed that the neck serves to give the animal
greater vigilance.[73][74]

### Internal systems

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Flickr_-_Rainbirder_-
_Reticulated_Giraffe_drinking.jpg/220px-Flickr_-_Rainbirder_-
_Reticulated_Giraffe_drinking.jpg)](/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Rainbirder_-
_Reticulated_Giraffe_drinking.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Rainbirder_-_Reticulated_Giraffe_drinking.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Reticulated giraffe](/wiki/Reticulated_giraffe "Reticulated giraffe") bending
down to drink, in [Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya"). The circulatory system is
adapted to deal with blood flow rushing down its neck.

In mammals, the left [recurrent laryngeal
nerve](/wiki/Recurrent_laryngeal_nerve "Recurrent laryngeal nerve") is longer
than the right; in the giraffe it is over 30 cm (12 in) longer. These nerves
are longer in the giraffe than in any other living animal;[75] the left nerve
is over 2 m (6 ft 7 in) long.[76] Each nerve cell in this path begins in the
[brainstem](/wiki/Brainstem "Brainstem") and passes down the neck along the
[vagus nerve](/wiki/Vagus_nerve "Vagus nerve"), then branches off into the
recurrent laryngeal nerve which passes back up the neck to the larynx. Thus,
these nerve cells have a length of nearly 5 m (16 ft) in the largest
giraffes.[75] The structure of a giraffe's brain resembles that of domestic
cattle.[53]:31 It is kept cool by evaporative heat loss in the nasal
passages.[54] The shape of the skeleton gives the giraffe a small lung volume
relative to its mass. Its long neck gives it a large amount of [dead
space](/wiki/Dead_space_\(physiology\) "Dead space \(physiology\)"), in spite
of its narrow windpipe. These factors increase the resistance to airflow.
Nevertheless, the animal can still supply enough oxygen to its tissues and it
can increase its respiratory rate and oxygen diffusion when running.[77]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Giraffe-Drinking-
Nairobi.JPG/220px-Giraffe-Drinking-Nairobi.JPG)](/wiki/File:Giraffe-Drinking-
Nairobi.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Giraffe-Drinking-Nairobi.JPG "Enlarge")

Giraffe's snout while drinking

The [circulatory system](/wiki/Circulatory_system "Circulatory system") of the
giraffe has several adaptations for its great height. Its heart, which can
weigh more than 11 kg (25 lb) and measures about 60 cm (2 ft) long, must
generate approximately double the blood pressure required for a human to
maintain blood flow to the brain. As such, the wall of the heart can be as
thick as 7.5 cm (3.0 in).[19] Giraffes have unusually high heart rates for
their size, at 150 beats per minute.[52]:76 When the animal lowers its head
the blood rushes down fairly unopposed and a [rete
mirabile](/wiki/Rete_mirabile "Rete mirabile") in the upper neck, with its
large [cross sectional](/wiki/Cross_section_\(geometry\) "Cross section
\(geometry\)") area, prevents excess blood flow to the brain. When it raises
again, the blood vessels constrict and direct blood into the brain so the
animal does not faint.[78] The [jugular veins](/wiki/Jugular_vein "Jugular
vein") contain several (most commonly seven) valves to prevent blood flowing
back into the head from the [inferior vena cava](/wiki/Inferior_vena_cava
"Inferior vena cava") and [right atrium](/wiki/Right_atrium "Right atrium")
while the head is lowered.[79] Conversely, the blood vessels in the lower legs
are under great pressure because of the weight of fluid pressing down on them.
To solve this problem, the skin of the lower legs is thick and tight;
preventing too much blood from pouring into them.[46]

Giraffes have [oesophageal muscles](/wiki/Esophagus "Esophagus") that are
unusually strong to allow regurgitation of food from the stomach up the neck
and into the mouth for [rumination](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/ruminate
"wikt:ruminate").[52]:78 They have four chambered stomachs, as in all
ruminants, and the first chamber has adapted to their specialised diet.[7] The
intestines of an adult giraffe measure more than 70 m (230 ft) in length and
have a relatively small ratio of small to large intestine.[80] The liver of
the giraffe is small and compact.[52]:76 A gallbladder is generally present
during fetal life, but it may disappear before birth.[7][81][82]

## Behaviour and ecology

### Habitat and feeding

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Giraffe_feeding%2C_Tanzania.jpg/220px-
Giraffe_feeding%2C_Tanzania.jpg)](/wiki/File:Giraffe_feeding,_Tanzania.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Giraffe_feeding,_Tanzania.jpg "Enlarge")

A [Masai giraffe](/wiki/Masai_giraffe "Masai giraffe") extending its tongue to
feed, in [Tanzania](/wiki/Tanzania "Tanzania"). Its tongue, lips and palate
are tough enough to deal with sharp thorns in trees.

Giraffes usually inhabit [savannahs](/wiki/Savannah "Savannah") and open
[woodlands](/wiki/Woodland "Woodland"). They prefer [Acacieae](/wiki/Acacieae
"Acacieae"), _[Commiphora](/wiki/Commiphora "Commiphora")_ ,
_[Combretum](/wiki/Combretum "Combretum")_ and open
_[Terminalia](/wiki/Terminalia_\(plant\) "Terminalia \(plant\)")_ woodlands
over denser environments like _[Brachystegia](/wiki/Brachystegia
"Brachystegia")_ woodlands.[40]:322 The Angolan giraffe can be found in desert
environments.[83] Giraffes browse on the twigs of trees, preferring trees of
the subfamily Acacieae and the genera _Commiphora_ and _Terminalia_ ,[4] which
are important sources of calcium and protein to sustain the giraffe's growth
rate.[11] They also feed on shrubs, grass and fruit.[40]:324 A giraffe eats
around 34 kg (75 lb) of foliage daily.[45] When stressed, giraffes may chew
the bark off branches. Although [herbivorous](/wiki/Herbivorous
"Herbivorous"), the giraffe has been known to visit carcasses and lick dried
meat off bones.[40]:325

During the wet season, food is abundant and giraffes are more spread out,
while during the dry season, they gather around the remaining evergreen trees
and bushes.[4] Mothers tend to feed in open areas, presumably to make it
easier to detect predators, although this may reduce their feeding
efficiency.[70] As a [ruminant](/wiki/Ruminant "Ruminant"), the giraffe first
chews its food, then swallows it for processing and then visibly passes the
half-digested cud up the neck and back into the mouth to chew again.[52]:78–79
It is common for a giraffe to salivate while feeding.[53]:27 The giraffe
requires less food than many other herbivores because the foliage it eats has
more concentrated nutrients and it has a more efficient digestive system.[4]
The animal's faeces come in the form of small pellets.[7] When it has access
to water, a giraffe drinks at intervals no longer than three days.[45]

Giraffes have a great effect on the trees that they feed on, delaying the
growth of young trees for some years and giving "waistlines" to trees that are
too tall.[45] Feeding is at its highest during the first and last hours of
daytime. Between these hours, giraffes mostly stand and ruminate. Rumination
is the dominant activity during the night, when it is mostly done lying
down.[45]

### Social life

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Giraffe_%28Giraffa_camelopardalis%29_females.jpg/220px-
Giraffe_%28Giraffa_camelopardalis%29_females.jpg)](/wiki/File:Giraffe_\(Giraffa_camelopardalis\)_females.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Giraffe_\(Giraffa_camelopardalis\)_females.jpg "Enlarge")

Gathering of female [southern giraffes](/wiki/South_African_giraffe "South
African giraffe") in [Tswalu Kalahari Reserve](/wiki/Tswalu_Kalahari_Reserve
"Tswalu Kalahari Reserve"), [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa").
These animals commonly gather in herds.

Giraffes are usually found in groups. Traditionally, the composition of these
groups has been described as open and ever-changing.[84] Giraffes were thought
to have few social bonds and for research purposes, a "group" has been defined
as "a collection of individuals that are less than a kilometre apart and
moving in the same general direction."[85] More recent studies have found that
giraffes do have long-term social associations and may form groups or pairs
based on kinship, sex or other factors. These groups may regularly associate
with one another in larger communities or sub-communities within a
[fission–fusion society](/wiki/Fission%E2%80%93fusion_society "Fission–fusion
society").[86][87][88] The number of giraffes in a group can range up to 44
individuals.[88]

Giraffe groups tend to be sex-segregated[88] although mixed-sex groups made of
adult females and young males are known to occur. Particularly stable giraffe
groups are those made of mothers and their young,[85] which can last weeks or
months.[89] Social cohesion in these groups is maintained by the bonds formed
between calves.[40]:330[85] Female association appears to be based on [space-
use](/wiki/Philopatry "Philopatry") and individuals may be
[matrilineally](/wiki/Matrilineally "Matrilineally") related.[88] In general,
females are more selective than males in who they associate with in regards to
individuals of the same sex.[87] Young males also form groups and will engage
in playfights. However, as they get older males become more solitary but may
also associate in pairs or with female groups.[88][89] Giraffes are not
[territorial](/wiki/Territory_\(animal\) "Territory \(animal\)"),[7] but they
have [home ranges](/wiki/Home_range "Home range").[45] Male giraffes
occasionally wander far from areas that they normally frequent.[40]:329

Although generally quiet and non-vocal, giraffes have been heard to
communicate using various sounds. During courtship, males emit loud
coughs.[45] Females call their young by bellowing. Calves will emit snorts,
bleats, mooing and mewing sounds. Giraffes also snore, hiss, moan, grunt and
make flute-like sounds,[45][90] and possibly communicate over long distances
using [infrasound](/wiki/Infrasound "Infrasound")[91]—though this is
disputed.[90] During nighttime, giraffes appear to [hum](/wiki/Humming
"Humming") to each other above the infrasound range for purposes which are
unclear.[90]

### Reproduction and parental care

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Giraffa_camelopardalis_angolensis_%28courting%29.jpg/200px-
Giraffa_camelopardalis_angolensis_%28courting%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Giraffa_camelopardalis_angolensis_\(courting\).jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Giraffa_camelopardalis_angolensis_%28mating%29.jpg/200px-
Giraffa_camelopardalis_angolensis_%28mating%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Giraffa_camelopardalis_angolensis_\(mating\).jpg)

[Southern giraffes](/wiki/Angolan_giraffe "Angolan giraffe") courting (above)
and mating in [Namibia](/wiki/Namibia "Namibia"). Generally, only dominant
males are able to mate with females.

Reproduction in giraffes is broadly [polygamous](/wiki/Polygamous
"Polygamous"): a few older males mate with the fertile females. Male giraffes
assess female fertility by tasting the female's urine to detect
[oestrus](/wiki/Oestrus "Oestrus"), in a multi-step process known as the
[flehmen response](/wiki/Flehmen_response "Flehmen response").[85][89] Males
prefer young adult females over juveniles and older adults.[85] Once an
oestrous female is detected, the male will attempt to court her. When
courting, dominant males will keep subordinate ones at bay.[89] A courting
male may lick a female's tail, rest his head and neck on her body or nudge her
with his horns. During copulation, the male stands on his hind legs with his
head held up and his front legs resting on the female's sides.[45]

Giraffe [gestation](/wiki/Gestation "Gestation") lasts 400–460 days, after
which a single calf is normally born, although twins occur on rare
occasions.[92] The mother gives birth standing up. The calf emerges head and
front legs first, having broken through the [fetal
membranes](/wiki/Fetal_membrane "Fetal membrane"), and falls to the ground,
severing the [umbilical cord](/wiki/Umbilical_cord "Umbilical cord").[7] The
mother then grooms the newborn and helps it stand up.[53]:40 A newborn giraffe
is 1.7–2 m (5.6–6.6 ft) tall.[47][48][49] Within a few hours of birth, the
calf can run around and is almost indistinguishable from a one-week-old.
However, for the first 1–3 weeks, it spends most of its time hiding;[93] its
coat pattern providing camouflage. The ossicones, which have lain flat while
it was in the womb, become erect within a few days.[45]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Giraffe_Family.jpg/220px-
Giraffe_Family.jpg)](/wiki/File:Giraffe_Family.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Giraffe_Family.jpg "Enlarge")

Mother [Masai giraffe](/wiki/Masai_giraffe "Masai giraffe") and calves feeding
in [Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya"). It is mostly the females that raise young,
and they may gather in nursery herds.

Mothers with calves will gather in nursery herds, moving or browsing together.
Mothers in such a group may sometimes leave their calves with one female while
they forage and drink elsewhere. This is known as a "[calving
pool](/wiki/Cr%C3%A8che_\(zoology\) "Crèche \(zoology\)")".[93] Adult males
play almost no role in raising the young,[40]:337 although they appear to have
friendly interactions.[85] Calves are at risk of predation, and a mother
giraffe will stand over her calf and kick at an approaching predator.[45]
Females watching calving pools will only alert their own young if they detect
a disturbance, although the others will take notice and follow.[93]

The length time in which offspring stay with their mother varies, though it
can last until the female's next calving.[93] Likewise, calves may suckle for
only a month[40]:335 or as long as a year.[45][89] Females become sexually
mature when they are four years old, while males become mature at four or five
years. [Spermatogenesis](/wiki/Spermatogenesis "Spermatogenesis") in male
giraffes begins at three to four years of age.[94] Males must wait until they
are at least seven years old to gain the opportunity to mate.[45][53]:40

### Necking

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Giraffe_Ithala_KZN_South_Africa_Luca_Galuzzi_2004.JPG/220px-
Giraffe_Ithala_KZN_South_Africa_Luca_Galuzzi_2004.JPG)](/wiki/File:Giraffe_Ithala_KZN_South_Africa_Luca_Galuzzi_2004.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Giraffe_Ithala_KZN_South_Africa_Luca_Galuzzi_2004.JPG "Enlarge")

Here, male [southern giraffes](/wiki/South_African_giraffe "South African
giraffe") engage in low intensity necking to establish dominance, in [Ithala
Game Reserve](/wiki/Ithala_Game_Reserve "Ithala Game Reserve"), [Kwa-Zulu-
Natal](/wiki/KwaZulu-Natal "KwaZulu-Natal"), [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa
"South Africa").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Giraffe-Necking-
Etosha.JPG/220px-Giraffe-Necking-Etosha.JPG)](/wiki/File:Giraffe-Necking-
Etosha.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Giraffe-Necking-Etosha.JPG "Enlarge")

The more active kind of necking, engaged with here by [southern
giraffes](/wiki/Angolan_giraffe "Angolan giraffe") in [Namibia](/wiki/Namibia
"Namibia").

Male giraffes use their necks as weapons in combat, a behaviour known as
"necking". Necking is used to establish dominance and males that win necking
bouts have greater [reproductive success](/wiki/Reproductive_success
"Reproductive success").[15] This behaviour occurs at low or high intensity.
In low intensity necking, the combatants rub and lean against each other. The
male that can hold itself more erect wins the bout. In high intensity necking,
the combatants will spread their front legs and swing their necks at each
other, attempting to land blows with their ossicones. The contestants will try
to dodge each other's blows and then get ready to counter. The power of a blow
depends on the weight of the skull and the arc of the swing.[45] A necking
duel can last more than half an hour, depending on how well matched the
combatants are.[40]:331 Although most fights do not lead to serious injury,
there have been records of broken jaws, broken necks, and even deaths.[15]

After a duel, it is common for two male giraffes to caress and court each
other. Such interactions between males have been found to be more frequent
than heterosexual coupling.[95] In one study, up to 94 percent of observed
mounting incidents took place between males. The proportion of same-sex
activities varied from 30–75 percent. Only one percent of same-sex mounting
incidents occurred between females.[96]

### Mortality and health

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Lioness_with_giraffe_kill%2C_jackal_lurking%2C_kenya%2C_august_9th_2012.jpg/220px-
Lioness_with_giraffe_kill%2C_jackal_lurking%2C_kenya%2C_august_9th_2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lioness_with_giraffe_kill,_jackal_lurking,_kenya,_august_9th_2012.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lioness_with_giraffe_kill,_jackal_lurking,_kenya,_august_9th_2012.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Lioness](/wiki/Lion "Lion") seen with an adult [Masai
giraffe](/wiki/Masai_giraffe "Masai giraffe") kill

Giraffes have high adult survival probability,[97] and an unusually long
lifespan compared to other ruminants,[98] up to 25 years in the wild.[46]
Because of their size, eyesight and powerful kicks, adult giraffes are usually
not subject to predation,[45] aside from [lions](/wiki/Lion "Lion").[99]
Giraffes are the most common prey for the big cats in [Kruger National
Park](/wiki/Kruger_National_Park "Kruger National Park").[100] [Nile
crocodiles](/wiki/Nile_crocodile "Nile crocodile") can also be a threat to
giraffes when they bend down to drink.[53] Calves are much more vulnerable
than adults, and are additionally preyed on by [leopards](/wiki/Leopard
"Leopard"), [spotted hyenas](/wiki/Spotted_hyena "Spotted hyena") and [wild
dogs](/wiki/African_wild_dog "African wild dog").[19] A quarter to a half of
giraffe calves reach adulthood.[97][101] Calf survival varies according to the
season of birth, with calves born during the dry season having higher survival
rates.[102] The local, seasonal presence of large herds of migratory
[wildebeests](/wiki/Wildebeest "Wildebeest") and [zebras](/wiki/Zebra "Zebra")
reduces predation pressure on giraffe calves and increases their survival
probability.[103]

Some parasites feed on giraffes. They are often hosts for [ticks](/wiki/Tick
"Tick"), especially in the area around the genitals, which has thinner skin
than other areas.[7] Tick species that commonly feed on giraffes are those of
genera _[Hyalomma](/wiki/Hyalomma "Hyalomma")_ , _[Amblyomma](/wiki/Amblyomma
"Amblyomma")_ and _[Rhipicephalus](/wiki/Rhipicephalus "Rhipicephalus")_.
Giraffes may rely on [red-billed](/wiki/Red-billed_Oxpecker "Red-billed
Oxpecker") and [yellow-billed oxpeckers](/wiki/Yellow-billed_oxpecker "Yellow-
billed oxpecker") to clean them of ticks and alert them to danger. Giraffes
host numerous species of internal parasite and are susceptible to various
diseases. They were victims of the (now eradicated) viral illness
[rinderpest](/wiki/Rinderpest "Rinderpest").[7] Giraffes can also suffer from
a skin disorder, which comes in the form of wrinkles,
[lesions](/wiki/Cutaneous_condition#Lesions "Cutaneous condition") or raw
[fissures](/wiki/Skin_fissure "Skin fissure"). In Tanzania, it appears to be
caused by a [nematode](/wiki/Nematode "Nematode"), and may be further affected
by secondary infections. As much as 79% of giraffes show signs of the disease
in [Ruaha National Park](/wiki/Ruaha_National_Park "Ruaha National Park"), but
is less prevalent in areas with fertile soils.[104][105][106]

## Relationship with humans

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Giraffe_cave_art.jpg/220px-
Giraffe_cave_art.jpg)](/wiki/File:Giraffe_cave_art.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Giraffe_cave_art.jpg "Enlarge")

[San rock art](/wiki/San_rock_art "San rock art") in Namibia depicting a
giraffe

Humans have interacted with giraffes for millennia. The [San
people](/wiki/San_people "San people") of southern Africa have medicine dances
named after some animals; the giraffe dance is performed to treat head
ailments.[107] How the giraffe got its height has been the subject of various
African [folktales](/wiki/Folklore "Folklore"),[15] including one from eastern
Africa which explains that the giraffe grew tall from eating too many magic
herbs.[108] Giraffes were depicted in art throughout the African continent,
including that of the [Kiffians](/wiki/Kiffian_culture "Kiffian culture"),
[Egyptians](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt") and [Meroë](/wiki/Mero%C3%AB
"Meroë") [Nubians](/wiki/Nubia "Nubia").[53]:45–47 The Kiffians were
responsible for a life-size rock engraving of two giraffes that has been
called the "world's largest rock art petroglyph".[53]:45[109] The Egyptians
gave the giraffe its own [hieroglyph](/wiki/Egyptian_hieroglyphs "Egyptian
hieroglyphs"), named 'sr' in [Old Egyptian](/wiki/Old_Egyptian_language "Old
Egyptian language") and 'mmy' in later periods.[53]:49 They also kept giraffes
as pets and shipped them around the Mediterranean.[53]:48–49

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg/220px-
Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tribute_Giraffe_with_Attendant.jpg "Enlarge")

Painting of a giraffe imported to China during the [Ming
dynasty](/wiki/Ming_dynasty "Ming dynasty")

The giraffe was also known to the [Greeks](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient
Greece") and [Romans](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome"), who believed that it
was an unnatural hybrid of a [camel](/wiki/Camel "Camel") and a leopard and
called it _camelopardalis_.[53]:50 The giraffe was among the many animals
collected and
[displayed](/wiki/Mosaic_Fragment_with_Man_Leading_a_Giraffe_\(Art_Institute_of_Chicago\)
"Mosaic Fragment with Man Leading a Giraffe \(Art Institute of Chicago\)") by
the Romans. The first one in Rome was brought in by [Julius
Caesar](/wiki/Julius_Caesar "Julius Caesar") in 46 BC and exhibited to the
public.[53]:52 With the [fall of the Western Roman
Empire](/wiki/Fall_of_the_Western_Roman_Empire "Fall of the Western Roman
Empire"), the housing of giraffes in Europe declined.[53]:54 During the
[Middle Ages](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages"), giraffes were known to
Europeans through contact with the Arabs, who revered the giraffe for its
peculiar appearance.[19]

Individual captive giraffes were given celebrity status throughout history. In
1414, a giraffe was shipped from [Malindi](/wiki/Malindi "Malindi") to
[Bengal](/wiki/Bengal "Bengal"). It was then [taken to
China](/wiki/Treasure_voyages "Treasure voyages") by explorer [Zheng
He](/wiki/Zheng_He "Zheng He") and placed in a [Ming
dynasty](/wiki/Ming_dynasty "Ming dynasty") zoo. The animal was a source of
fascination for the Chinese people, who associated it with the mythical
[Qilin](/wiki/Qilin "Qilin").[53]:56 The [Medici giraffe](/wiki/Medici_giraffe
"Medici giraffe") was a giraffe presented to [Lorenzo de'
Medici](/wiki/Lorenzo_de%27_Medici "Lorenzo de' Medici") in 1486. It caused a
great stir on its arrival in [Florence](/wiki/Florence "Florence").[110]
[Zarafa](/wiki/Zarafa_\(giraffe\) "Zarafa \(giraffe\)"), another famous
giraffe, was brought from
[Egypt](/wiki/History_of_Egypt_under_the_Muhammad_Ali_dynasty "History of
Egypt under the Muhammad Ali dynasty") to Paris in the early 19th century as a
gift from [Muhammad Ali of Egypt](/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_of_Egypt "Muhammad Ali of
Egypt") to [Charles X of France](/wiki/Charles_X_of_France "Charles X of
France"). A sensation, the giraffe was the subject of numerous memorabilia or
"giraffanalia".[53]:81

Giraffes continue to have a presence in modern culture. [Salvador
Dalí](/wiki/Salvador_Dal%C3%AD "Salvador Dalí") depicted them with burning
manes in some of his surrealist paintings. Dali considered the giraffe to be a
symbol of masculinity, and a flaming giraffe was meant to be a "masculine
cosmic apocalyptic monster".[53]:123 Several children's books feature the
giraffe, including David A. Ufer's _The Giraffe Who Was Afraid of Heights_ ,
[Giles Andreae](/wiki/Giles_Andreae "Giles Andreae")'s _Giraffes Can 't Dance_
and [Roald Dahl](/wiki/Roald_Dahl "Roald Dahl")'s _[The Giraffe and the Pelly
and Me](/wiki/The_Giraffe_and_the_Pelly_and_Me "The Giraffe and the Pelly and
Me")_. Giraffes have appeared in animated films, as minor characters in
[Disney](/wiki/Disney "Disney")'s _[The Lion King](/wiki/The_Lion_King "The
Lion King")_ and _[Dumbo](/wiki/Dumbo "Dumbo")_ , and in more prominent roles
in _[The Wild](/wiki/The_Wild "The Wild")_ and in the
_[Madagascar](/wiki/Madagascar_\(franchise\) "Madagascar \(franchise\)")_
films. [Sophie the Giraffe](/wiki/Sophie_the_Giraffe "Sophie the Giraffe") has
been a popular [teether](/wiki/Teether "Teether") since 1961. Another famous
fictional giraffe is the Toys "R" Us mascot [Geoffrey the
Giraffe](/wiki/Toys_%22R%22_Us#Geoffrey_the_Giraffe "Toys "R" Us").[53]:127

The giraffe has also been used for some scientific experiments and
discoveries. Scientists have looked at the properties of giraffe skin when
developing suits for [astronauts](/wiki/Astronaut "Astronaut") and [fighter
pilots](/wiki/Fighter_pilot "Fighter pilot")[52]:76 because the people in
these professions are in danger of passing out if blood rushes to their legs.
Computer scientists have modeled the coat patterns of several subspecies using
[reaction–diffusion](/wiki/Reaction%E2%80%93diffusion "Reaction–diffusion")
mechanisms.[111]

The [constellation](/wiki/Constellation "Constellation") of
[Camelopardalis](/wiki/Camelopardalis "Camelopardalis"), introduced in the
seventeenth century, depicts a giraffe.[53]:119–20 The [Tswana
people](/wiki/Tswana_people "Tswana people") of Botswana traditionally see the
constellation [Crux](/wiki/Crux "Crux") as two giraffes – [Acrux](/wiki/Acrux
"Acrux") and [Mimosa](/wiki/Beta_Crucis "Beta Crucis") forming a male, and
[Gacrux](/wiki/Gacrux "Gacrux") and [Delta Crucis](/wiki/Delta_Crucis "Delta
Crucis") forming the female.[112]

### Exploitation and conservation status

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Bundesarchiv_Bild_105-DOA0377%2C_Deutsch-
Ostafrika%2C_Giraffe.jpg/220px-Bundesarchiv_Bild_105-DOA0377%2C_Deutsch-
Ostafrika%2C_Giraffe.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_105-DOA0377,_Deutsch-
Ostafrika,_Giraffe.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_105-DOA0377,_Deutsch-Ostafrika,_Giraffe.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Masai giraffe](/wiki/Masai_giraffe "Masai giraffe") killed by tribesmen in
[German East Africa](/wiki/German_East_Africa "German East Africa") during the
early 20th century

Giraffes were probably common targets for hunters throughout Africa.[40]
Different parts of their bodies were used for different purposes.[7] Their
meat was used for food. The tail hairs served as
[flyswatters](/wiki/Flyswatter "Flyswatter"), bracelets, necklaces and
thread.[7][40] Shields, sandals and drums were made using the skin, and the
strings of musical instruments were from the tendons.[7] The smoke from
burning giraffe skins was used by the medicine men of [Buganda](/wiki/Buganda
"Buganda") to treat nose bleeds.[40] The Humr people of Sudan consume the
drink Umm Nyolokh; which is created from the liver and marrow of giraffes. Umm
Nyolokh often contains [DMT](/wiki/N,N-Dimethyltryptamine
"N,N-Dimethyltryptamine") and other psychoactive substances from plants the
giraffes eat such as Acacia; and is known to cause hallucinations of giraffes,
believed to be the giraffes' ghosts by the Humr.[113][114] In the 19th
century, European explorers began to hunt them for sport.[53] Habitat
destruction has hurt the giraffe, too: in the [Sahel](/wiki/Sahel "Sahel"),
the need for firewood and grazing room for livestock has led to
[deforestation](/wiki/Deforestation "Deforestation"). Normally, giraffes can
coexist with livestock, since they do not directly compete with them.[46] In
2017, severe droughts in northern Kenya have led to increased tensions over
land and the killing of wildlife by herders, with giraffe populations being
particularly hit.[115]

Aerial survey is the most common method of monitoring giraffe population
trends in the vast roadless tracts of African landscapes, but aerial methods
are known to undercount giraffes.[116] Ground-based survey methods are more
accurate and should be used in conjunction with aerial surveys to make
accurate estimates of population sizes and trends.[116] In 2010, giraffes were
assessed as [Least Concern](/wiki/Least_Concern "Least Concern") from a
conservation perspective by the [International Union for Conservation of
Nature](/wiki/International_Union_for_Conservation_of_Nature "International
Union for Conservation of Nature") (IUCN), but the 2016 assessment categorized
giraffes as [Vulnerable](/wiki/Vulnerable_species "Vulnerable species").[1]
Giraffes have been [extirpated](/wiki/Local_extinction "Local extinction")
from much of their historic range including [Eritrea](/wiki/Eritrea
"Eritrea"), [Guinea](/wiki/Guinea "Guinea"), [Mauritania](/wiki/Mauritania
"Mauritania") and [Senegal](/wiki/Senegal "Senegal"). They may also have
disappeared from [Angola](/wiki/Angola "Angola"), [Mali](/wiki/Mali "Mali"),
and [Nigeria](/wiki/Nigeria "Nigeria"), but have been introduced to
[Rwanda](/wiki/Rwanda "Rwanda") and [Swaziland](/wiki/Swaziland
"Swaziland").[1] Two subspecies, the [West African
giraffe](/wiki/West_African_giraffe "West African giraffe") and the
[Rothschild giraffe](/wiki/Rothschild_giraffe "Rothschild giraffe"), have been
classified as [endangered](/wiki/Endangered_species "Endangered
species"),[38][37] as wild populations of each of them number in the hundreds.

In 1997, [Jonathan Kingdon](/wiki/Jonathan_Kingdon "Jonathan Kingdon")
suggested that the [Nubian giraffe](/wiki/Nubian_giraffe "Nubian giraffe") was
the most threatened of all giraffes;[4] as of
2010[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Giraffe&action=edit), it
may number fewer than 250, although this estimate is uncertain. Private game
reserves have contributed to the preservation of giraffe populations in
southern Africa.[46] [Giraffe Manor](/wiki/Giraffe_Manor "Giraffe Manor") is a
popular hotel in [Nairobi](/wiki/Nairobi "Nairobi") that also serves as
sanctuary for Rothschild's giraffes.[117] The giraffe is a protected species
in most of its range. It is the [national animal](/wiki/National_animal
"National animal") of Tanzania,[118] and is protected by law.[119]
Unauthorised killing can result in imprisonment.[120] The UN backed Convention
of Migratory Species selected giraffes for protection in 2017.[121] In 1999,
it was estimated that over 140,000 giraffes existed in the wild,[34]
estimations as of 2016 indicate that there are approximately 97,500 members of
_Giraffa_ in the wild, down from 155,000 in 1985, with around 1,144 in
captivity.[122][123][_[full citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include
"Wikipedia:Citing sources")_]
